fields.label_text:
CHANDELIER
ENGLISH; about 1690
Gilt wood

One of a set of six which formerly hung in the Queen's Gallery at Kensington Palace.

Given in memory of Mr. S. Atkin.

fields.descriptive_line: A chandelier of carved and gilded wood; English, late seventeenth century.
fields.physical_description: A chandelier of carved and gilded wood with twelve s-scroll branches carved with acanthus foliage and ending in brass sockets. The vase-shaped stem, surmounted by a royal crown and ornamented with lambrequins and pendant husks, has a fixed ring at the base of the stem for raising and lowering the chandelier.
fields.label:
CHANDELIER
ENGLISH; about 1690
Gilt wood

One of a set of six which formerly hung in the Queen's Gallery at Kensington Palace.

Given in memory of Mr. S. Atkin. [pre October 2000]
fields.public_access_description:
An English chandelier of carved and gilded wood with twelve s-scroll branches carved with acanthus foliage and ending in brass sockets. The vase-shaped stem, surmounted by a royal crown and ornamented with lambrequins and pendant husks, has a fixed ring at the base of the stem for raising and lowering the chandelier.

The chandelier forms part of a set of six whch formerly hung in the Queen's gallery at Kensington Palace. The set was sold from Kensington Palace, probably in the late nineteenth century, and passed to Brympton d'Evercy in Somerset.    

On loan to Kensington Palace.
fields.history_note:
Notes from R.P. 59/3481

4/11/59 Listed on V & A "Objects submitted on Approval for Purchase" 
Along with a walnut bureau as: Carved gilt chandlier from Brympton D'Evercy, formerly at Kensington Palace, English about 1690, £414.

13/4/59 letter from Amyas Phillips of Phillips of Hitchin Ltd
states "I shall be pleased to give you a sight of my invoices etc. in proof that the carved gilt chandelier made for King William III at Kensington Palace has cost me £739.16.11 expenses in buying it and supervising its repairs.  I am pleased to offer this chandelier to the Museum at 10% profit….totalling £814."

Typed notes of 7/1/60
explain that the chandelier and a bureau were acquired by exchange of 18th C. chairs.  It  describes the chandelier: "dates from the late 17th or early 18th century and probably forms part of the original furnishings of Kensington Palace.  It is one of a set of six which formerly hung in the Queen's Gallery at the Palace, and which are shown in the view of that Gallery in Pyne's 'Royal Residences', p.67.  This volume was published in 1819 and the chandeliers remained in the Palace until the end of the 19th century when they were sold.  Three of them were purchased by Sir Spencer Ponsonby Fane for his house at Brympton d'Evercy, when they were sold a few years ago.  It is one of these three that has now been acquired".

Other references in the files are in connection with the exchange transaction.

Phillips of Hitchin Ltd, Invoice
"One of a set of carved gilt chandeliers from Brympton D'Evercy, formerly at Kensington Palace" £814 
(with walnut bureau £600 - by contra £1000 credit for chairs = £414 purchase price)

Phillips of Hitchin letter 26/9/59 notes
"I have already sold the companion chandelier for a considerably higher price…."
